Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Patient Blood Management in Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group, receiving care based on the updated guidelines, or the control group, receiving standard care.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults scheduled for cardiac surgery at participating European hospitals.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received care based on the updated PBM guidelines, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: To assess the impact of updated PBM guidelines on patient outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of bleeding complications within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in bleeding complications (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: The trial was funded by the EACTS and EACTAIC.
